results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Fascinating Fiji’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 drive through a plantation
00:01:05:00 buffalo
00:01:31:00 sign for the Raki Raki Hotel.
00:03:44:00 seaside township
00:04:10:00 foraging on the foreshore.
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Welcome to Nausori’ before crossing the (old) Rewa bridge by car.
00:04:56:00 ‘Nausori Municipal Market’ on the island of ‘Viti Levu’ showing various vegetable stalls and some produce boxes from New Zealand.
00:05:45:00 sign for ‘Kings Road’ showing miles to various destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Arnhem Land’, contains scenes from a trip to Arnhem Land and Katherine in the Northern Territory in the 1970s.

Travel is by jeep on dusty roads, boats and walking. Wallace captures the varied landscapes of rivers, rocky outcrops, hills, trees, flowers and the scrub as well as termite mounds. He also films buffalo, lizards and waterbirds. A highlight is the Aboriginal rock art drawings throughout the film.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Arnhem Land Safari’
00:01:08:00 sign for the township of Katherine in the Northern Territory.
00:02:05:00 truck travels along a dirt road with scrub burning-off on either side.
00:02:29:00 truck travelling crossing a river.
00:02:48:00 pictorial map of the Jim Jim Falls area.
00:03:28:00 canvas tents at a campsite.
00:06:55:00 four wheel drive and trailer.
00:07:52:00 water buffalo.
00:08:00:00 very large bird in equally large nest at the top of a tree.
00:14:30:00 sign ‘Northern Territory Administration Aboriginal Reserve’.
00:13:45:00 examples of Aboriginal rock art drawings which appear until the end of the reel.
00:24:50:00 swimsuits of the era while swimming in a river.
00:27:00:00 digging a tourist bus out of a sandy track.
00:28:58:00 skeletal remains in the mouth of a cave.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

In this film, the filmmaker shows life on and around the beach at Anglesea in Victoria - walking, hang gliding, surfing, motoring in the dunes and on the sand, taking in the views from the cliffs. Wallace focuses on examples of coastal wildflowers as well as animal life where he finds it.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:06:46:00 hikers in the dunes.
00:11:00:00 a large snake in a tree.
00:11:25:00 hang gliding off the cliffs.
00:13:28:00 walkers on the beach.
00:15:23:00 a crab in the shallows.
00:16:04:00 surfing.
00:18:54:00 a jeep pulling a stuck ‘Holden’ station wagon car from the sand.
00:19:30:00 women looking over the view from the dunes.
00:19:54:00 a ‘jeep’ vehicle charging up a steep dune track.

results.title: 14's good, 18's better
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Timothy Read, Hilary Linstead, Film Australia, M and L and Big Picture
results.brief_description: A longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, now 18, intercut with footage from “Smokes and lollies”, shot when they were 14. Their previous expectations have been altered by the experiences of marriage, parenthood, employment, low incomes and insecurity. However, they remain optimistic, with their humour intact. (Awards: Winner, Best Australian Educational Short Film, Australian Teachers of Media (ATOM) Awards, 1982)

results.title: 15' Zondergrond = 15' Metromania = 15 Metromania
results.creator_credit: Bert Hamelinck, Karl Huysmans and Bart Van den Bempt
results.brief_description: Bernd is the new security guard at the Metro underground. Just as he relaxes into the position, a stern boss dictates some impossible rules and young Bernd’s day goes from bad to worse. Drawing on the aesthetic of the surveillance industry, director Bart Van den Bempt parallels surveillance type images alongside the running plot with split screens. As Bernd, infatuation by a young woman, tracks her movements using the security cameras, we the audience tour the process of security camera surveillance. The film style and structure become bound to the processes of surveillance, whilst the process of surveillance informs the film structure (specifically the narrative and the editing style).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bert Hamelinck, Karl Huysmans and Bart Van den Bempt

results.title: 147 break
results.creator_credit: Eric Harrison, Paul Doherty and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: Steve Davis became the first man in history to pot 15 reds, 15 blacks, plus all the colours in sequence under tournament conditions on television. This thrilling achievement is seen through Steve’s own eyes as he talks the viewer through the most difficult moments. Reminiscent of the “Pot Black” series and a must for snooker lovers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eric Harrison, Paul Doherty and Granada Television International

results.title: 12,000 men
results.creator_credit: Martin Duckworth, Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This powerful documentary brings alive the brave story of Cape Breton’s union struggles in the coal and steel industries from the 1890s through the labour wars of the 1920s. The fight for decent wages and improved working conditions took on an urgency when the British Empire Steel Corporation, or BESCO, bought every single steel and coal company in Nova Scotia. When the Montreal-based company cut wages by a third, a long and bitter dispute began. The lockouts, picket lines and strikes were finally ended by brute force when provincial police and federal troops were sent in. The mine owners, however, were ultimately forced to recognize the union. This film combines vintage footage, photographs, drawings and interviews with men and women who were actually in the pits and on the front lines. These Cape Bretoners speak of the hardship and brief victories of the coal miners and their families. Photography by Martin Duckworth. Editing by Martin Duckworth and Shelagh Mackenzie. Sound by Patricia Kipping. Voice and narration by Kenzie MacNeil. (Awards: Yorkton)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Duckworth, Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada

This film combines vintage footage, photographs, drawings and interviews with men and women who were actually in the pits and on the front lines. These Cape Bretoners speak of the hardship and brief victories of the coal miners and their families. Photography by Martin Duckworth. Editing by Martin Duckworth and Shelagh Mackenzie. Sound by Patricia Kipping. Voice and narration by Kenzie MacNeil. (Awards: Yorkton)
description_for_label: This powerful documentary brings alive the brave story of Cape Breton’s union struggles in the coal and steel industries from the 1890s through the labour wars of the 1920s. The fight for decent wages and improved working conditions took on an urgency when the British Empire Steel Corporation, or BESCO, bought every single steel and coal company in Nova Scotia. When the Montreal-based company cut wages by a third, a long and bitter dispute began. The lockouts, picket lines and strikes were finally ended by brute force when provincial police and federal troops were sent in. The mine owners, however, were ultimately forced to recognize the union. This film combines vintage footage, photographs, drawings and interviews with men and women who were actually in the pits and on the front lines. These Cape Bretoners speak of the hardship and brief victories of the coal miners and their families. Photography by Martin Duckworth. Editing by Martin Duckworth and Shelagh Mackenzie. Sound by Patricia Kipping. Voice and narration by Kenzie MacNeil. (Awards: Yorkton)

results.title: 101 dalmatians
results.creator_credit: Stephen Herek, Ricardo Mestres, John Hughes, Walt Disney Pictures and Great Oaks
results.brief_description: This live-action adapted version of Dodie Smith’s classic children’s story will delight and amaze the whole family. Cruella De Vil (Glenn Close) is a woman with a passionate obsession for fur coats. Her quest is to have a coat made from the skin of the sweet dalmation pups owned by Anita and her husband Roger. The pups are kidnapped by two bumbling henchmen and Pongo and Perdita, the pups’ parents, enlist a canine army to execute a daring rescue. The special effects are outstanding as are the performances by an excellent cast, particularly Glenn Close. Co-starring Joely Richardson, Jeff Daniels, Joan Plowright and Hugh Laurie.

results.title: 100% Parlants et Chantants (1930-1933) Pt. 02
results.brief_description:
Part 2 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. By 1930 it becomes clear that the ‘talkies’ are here to stay and all eyes are turned to the USA. American (RCA, Western Electric) and German (TobisKlangFilm) sound systems are quickly adopted, as well as the short-lived routine of filming several language versions of the same film with different sets of actors. Paramount sets up a studio in Joinville, other studios are buit in Epinay, Boulogne-Billancourt as well as in the South of France (Nice/La Victorine). The production level re-establishes itself around 100 to 120 films per year. Germany’s ‘The Blue Angel’ is the first sub-titled film released in Paris. With this film, talkies become all singing and dancing. The advent of the sound era is also a turning point for many careers. Many film actors must accept that their voice is unsuitable for the new medium, while many stage actors discover that their voice training can open the door to a new career. This is the case for Gaby Morlay and especially for Raimu, whose tonitruant voice can win over microphones that are neither sensitive nor directional. Among the stand-out films of this era are Gremillon’s ‘La petite Lise’ (1929), Rene Clair’s ‘Le Million’ (X000265) and ‘A nous la liberte’ (X000158). [*=held in our collection]

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Casard.
Interviewees include: Rene Clair, Pierre Braunberger, Marcel L’Herbier, Yves Allegret, Henri-George Clouzot.

results.title: 100 years: the Australian story
results.creator_credit: Deborah Masters, Sue Spencer and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: A documentary of Australia, one of the world’s oldest democracies, this extensive and thorough series traces Australian political history. Themes of empire, independence, multiculturalism and indigenous Australia make up this enlightening series. Politicians, activists, experts and everyday Australians contributed to this powerful, educational documentary.
